comments:
Build: 3.0 RC1

1) Did a text search for a string inside a *.java file
2) Double-clicked on the search result to open the file.
3) Closed the search results view.
4) Deleted the reference in the java file and hit Ctrl+S.

John, is this repeateable for you? I'm trying to assess wether this is just a
timing issue (i.e. a posted runnable is executed in the wrong order) or wether
we're not deregistering a listener correctly. I have been able to recreate this
(i.e. get an exception), but no reliably.

I get it occasionally (three times yesterday, from looking at my log). The bug
looks pretty straight-forward - whenever you do an asyncExec or a UIJob, the
widget you are operating on might no longer exist when the job or runnable
finally executes, because another event ahead of it in the queue might dipose
the widget. It looks like you just need an if (!isDisposed()) check somewhere.

I got a similar error. It might be a timing problem. 
I'm not 100% sure what I did to get the error, but something like:
- search
- close the search view
- open the search view
- clicking on some items
- running a search again

(I might have closed the view while a background search was running)

The commonality with Johns backtrace is, that I closed the search view!

I can reproduce this quite easily (3.0 RC1 build):

1) Close search results view
2) Select a Java method and do Ctrl+Shift+G (global search)
3) Immediately close the search results view when it opens.
